Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and Bible beside me, notes scattered everywhere. The sermon for Sunday pressed on my mind—I needed to find the right words to guide my congregation, to help them navigate the moral choices they faced every day. I was deep in thought, searching for a passage that would resonate, when my husband walked in, dropping his bag with a sigh. He mentioned, almost offhand, that work had been stressful—nothing major, just a tough meeting and a few deadlines. I nodded, half-listening, my mind still tangled in scripture and sermon outlines. But then I caught the look in his eyes, the quiet hope for comfort, for a listening ear. I felt the pull—my role as his wife, to be present, to offer warmth and understanding. Yet the weight of my pastoral duty pressed just as hard, the expectation that I would be prepared, insightful, ready to lead. I sat there, torn, the demands of both roles heavy on my shoulders, unsure which voice to answer first.
